rule.name: Assigning an address value to an integer (int/long/etc.) type is not portable
rule.description:
Assigning a pointer to an integer (int/long/etc) is not portable across different platforms and compilers. For example in 32-bit Windows and linux they are same width, but in 64-bit Windows and linux they are of different width. In worst case you end up assigning 64-bit address to 32-bit integer. The safe way is to store addresses only in pointer types (or typedefs like uintptr_t).

References

CWE-758: Reliance on Undefined, Unspecified, or Implementation-Defined Behavior

rule.name: Assigning an integer (int/long/etc) to a pointer is not portable
rule.description:
Assigning an integer (int/long/etc) to a pointer is not portable across different platforms and compilers. For example in 32-bit Windows and linux they are same width, but in 64-bit Windows and linux they are of different width. In worst case you end up assigning 64-bit integer to 32-bit pointer. The safe way is to store addresses only in pointer types (or typedefs like uintptr_t).

References

CWE-758: Reliance on Undefined, Unspecified, or Implementation-Defined Behavior

rule.name: Assigning address of local auto-variable to a function parameter
rule.description:
Dangerous assignment - the function parameter is assigned the address of a local auto-variable. Local auto-variables are reserved from the stack which is freed when the function ends. So the pointer to a local variable is invalid after the function ends

  • Function parameter is assigned the address of a local auto-variable.
  • Local auto-variables are reserved from the stack which is freed when
  • the function ends. The address is invalid after the function ends and it
  • might 'leak' from the function through the parameter

    • References

    CWE-562: Return of Stack Variable Address
rule.gapDescription: auto-variable is not available after function returns

rule.name: The buffer may not be zero-terminated after the call to strncpy()
rule.description: The buffer 'varname' may not be null-terminated after the call to strncpy(). If the source string's size fits or exceeds the given size, strncpy() does not add a zero at the end of the buffer. This causes bugs later in the code if the code assumes buffer is null-terminated.

rule.name: Negative array index
rule.description:
Negative array index is always out of bounds.

References

ARR30-C. Do not form or use out-of-bounds pointers or array subscripts

CWE-786: Access of Memory Location Before Start of Buffer

rule.description:

rule.name: Undefined behavior, pointer arithmetic 'expr' or index is out of bounds
rule.description:
Undefined behaviour, pointer arithmetic 'expr' or index is out of bounds. From chapter 6.5.6 in the C specification:\n" "When an expression that has integer type is added to or subtracted from a pointer, .." and then "If both the pointer operand and the result point to elements of the same array object, or one past the last element of the array object, the evaluation shall not produce an overflow; otherwise, the behavior is undefined."

References

CWE-398: Indicator of Poor Code Quality

rule.name: Array index is used before limits check
rule.description:
Array index is used before limits check.

References

ARR30-C. Do not form or use out-of-bounds pointers or array subscripts

CWE-398: Indicator of Poor Code Quality

rule.name: Class does not have a constructor
rule.description:
The struct or class 'classname' does not have a constructor although it has private member variables. Member variables of builtin types are left uninitialized when the class is instantiated. That may cause bugs or undefined behavior.

References

CWE-398: Indicator of Poor Code Quality

rule.description:
Uninitialized variable.

References

CWE-908: Use of Uninitialized Resource

rule.name: Unused private function
rule.description:
Unused private function.

References

CWE-398: Indicator of Poor Code Quality

rule.name: Invalid usage of memset|memmove|memcpy on classes
rule.description:
Usage of the functions from the memset-family on classes should be avoided because it leads to undefined behavior in a number of cases (e.g. when the class contains a virtual method). Use constructors or init-routines to initialize your members instead

References

CWE-762: Mismatched Memory Management Routines

rule.name: 'class::operator=' should return 'class &'
rule.description:
The 'className::operator=' does not conform to standard C/C++ behaviour. To conform to standard C/C++ behaviour, return a reference to self (such as: className &className::operator=(..) { .. return *this; } For safety reasons it might be better to not fix this message. If you think that safety is always more important than conformance then please ignore/suppress this message. For more details about this topic, see the book "Effective C++" by Scott Meyers.

References

CWE-398: Indicator of Poor Code Quality

rule.name: Suspicious pointer subtraction
rule.description:
Suspicious pointer subtraction. Did you intend to write '->'?

References

CWE-398: Indicator of Poor Code Quality

rule.name: 'operator=' should return reference to self
rule.description:
'operator=' should return reference to self.

References

rule.name: 'operator=' should check for assignment to self
rule.description:
'operator=' should check for assignment to self to ensure that each block of dynamically allocated memory is owned and managed by only one instance of the class.

References

CWE-398: Indicator of Poor Code Quality

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'bcmp'
rule.description: The function 'bcmp' is obsolete. It is recommended that new applications use the 'memcmp' function.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'bcopy'
rule.description: The function 'bcopy' is obsolete. It is recommended that new applications use the 'memmove' or 'memcpy' functions.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'bsd_signal'
rule.description: The function 'bsd_signal' is obsolete. It is recommended that new applications use the 'sigaction' function.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'bzero'
rule.description: The function 'bzero' is obsolete. It is recommended that new applications use the 'memset' function.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'ecvt'
rule.description: The function 'ecvt' is obsolete. It is recommended that new applications use the 'sprintf' function

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'fcvt'
rule.description: The function 'fcvt' is obsolete. It is recommended that new applications use the 'sprintf' function.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'ftime'
rule.description: The function 'ftime' is obsolete.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'gcvt'
rule.description: The function 'gcvt' is obsolete. It is recommended that new applications use the 'sprintf' function.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'getcontext'
rule.description: The function 'getcontext' is obsolete. Due to portability issues with this function, applications are recommended to be rewritten to use POSIX threads.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'gethostbyaddr'
rule.description: The function 'gethostbyaddr' is obsolete. It is recommended that new applications use the 'getnameinfo' function.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'gethostbyname'
rule.description: The function 'gethostbyname' is obsolete. It is recommended that new applications use the 'getaddrinfo' function.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'gets'
rule.description: The function 'gets' is obsolete. It is recommended that new applications use the 'fgets' function instead.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'getwd'
rule.description: The function 'getwd' is obsolete. It is recommended that new applications use the 'getcwd' function.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'index'
rule.description: The function 'index' is obsolete. It is recommended to use the function 'strchr' instead.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'makecontext'
rule.description: The function 'makecontext' is obsolete. Due to portability issues with this function, applications are recommended to be rewritten to use POSIX threads.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'pthread_attr_getstackaddr'
rule.description: The function 'pthread_attr_getstackaddr' is obsolete. It is recommended that new applications use the 'pthread_attr_getstack' function.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'pthread_attr_setstackaddr'
rule.description: The function 'pthread_attr_setstackaddr' is obsolete. It is recommended that new applications use the 'pthread_attr_setstack' function.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'rindex'
rule.description: The function 'rindex' is obsolete. It is recommended to use the function 'strrchr' instead.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'scalb'
rule.description: The function 'scalb' is obsolete. It is recommended to use either 'scalbln', 'scalblnf' or 'scalblnl' instead of this function.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'swapcontext'
rule.description: The function 'swapcontext' is obsolete. Due to portability issues with this function, applications are recommended to be rewritten to use POSIX threads.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'ualarm'
rule.description: The function 'ualarm' is obsolete. It is recommended to use either 'timer_create', 'timer_delete', 'timer_getoverrun', 'timer_gettime', or 'timer_settime' instead of this function.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'usleep'
rule.description: The function 'usleep' is obsolete. It is recommended that new applications use the 'nanosleep' or 'setitimer' function.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'vfork'
rule.description: The function 'vfork' is obsolete. It is recommended to use the function 'fork' instead.

rule.name: Avoid usage of the function 'wcswcs'
rule.description: The function 'wcswcs' is obsolete. It is recommended to use the function 'wcsstr' instead.

rule.name: Clarify calculation precedence for + and ?
rule.description: Clarify calculation precedence for + and ?

rule.name: Suspicious condition (assignment+comparison)
rule.description:
• Suspicious condition (assignment+comparison), it can be clarified with parentheses.
    • Suspicious expression. Boolean result is used in bitwise operation. The operator '!' and the comparison operators have higher precedence than bitwise operators. It is recommended that the expression is clarified with parentheses.Suspicious condition (bitwise operator + comparison). Comparison operators have higher precedence than bitwise operators. Please clarify the condition with parentheses.

    References

    CWE-398: Indicator of Poor Code Quality

rule.name: Mismatch of the string literal and length argument for substr()
rule.description: String literal doesn't match length argument for substr().

rule.name: Suspicious use of the postfix '++' operator on a boolean
rule.description:
The operand of a postfix increment operator may be of type bool but it is deprecated by C++ Standard (Annex D-1) and the operand is always set to true. You should assign it the value 'true' instead.

CWE-398: Indicator of Poor Code Quality

rule.name: Suspicious condition. The result of find is an iterator, but it is not properly checked
rule.description: Suspicious condition. The result of find is an iterator, but it is not properly checked.

rule.name: Suspicious checking of string::find() return value
rule.description: Inefficient usage of string::find in condition. string::find will return '0' if the string is found at position '0'. If this is what you want to check then string::compare is a faster alternative because it doesn't scan through the string.

rule.name: Dangerous usage of c_str(). The returned value by c_str() is invalid after this call
rule.description:
Dangerous usage of c_str(). The returned value by c_str() is invalid after this call.

References

CWE-664: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime

rule.name: Prefer .empty() to .size() == 0 for emptiness checking
rule.description: Possible inefficient checking for emptiness. Using .empty() instead of .size() can be faster.

rule.name: Redundant checking of STL container element
rule.description: Redundant checking of STL container element.

rule.name: Be careful when using 'auto_ptr' copy
rule.description: Copy 'auto_ptr' pointer to another do not create two equal objects since one has lost its ownership of the pointer.

rule.name: Don't store 'auto-ptr' in a STL container
rule.description:
You can randomly lose access to pointers if you store 'auto_ptr' pointers in a container because the copy-semantics of 'auto_ptr' are not compatible with containers. An element of container must be able to be copied but 'auto_ptr' does not fulfill this requirement. You should consider to use 'shared_ptr' or 'unique_ptr'. It is suitable for use in containers, because they no longer copy their values, they move them.

References

CWE-664: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime

rule.name: Usage of 'auto_ptr' for pointers obtained with operator 'new[]'
rule.description:
Object pointed by an 'auto_ptr' is destroyed using operator 'delete'. This means that you should only use 'auto_ptr' for pointers obtained with operator 'new'. This excludes arrays, which are allocated by operator 'new[]' and must be deallocated by operator 'delete[]'.

References

CWE-664: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime

rule.name: Dangerous usage of variable (strncpy doesn't always 0-terminate it)
rule.description:
Dangerous usage of variable (strncpy doesn't always 0-terminate it).

CWE-676: Use of Potentially Dangerous Function

rule.name: Data is allocated but not initialized
rule.description:
Data is allocated but not initialized.

EXP33-C. Do not read uninitialized memory

CWE-908: Use of Uninitialized Resource

rule.name: Unused function
rule.description: The function is never used.

rule.name: Unused variable
rule.description: Unused variable.

rule.name: Variable is allocated memory that is never used
rule.description: Variable is allocated memory that is never used.

rule.name: Unused value
rule.description: Variable is assigned a value that is never used.

rule.name: Variable is not assigned a value
rule.description: Variable is not assigned a value.

rule.name: Unused struct or union member
rule.description: Struct or union member is never used.

rule.name: Prefer prefix ++/-- operators for non-primitive types
rule.description: Pre-increment/decrement can be more efficient than post-increment/decrement. Post-increment/decrement usually involves keeping a copy of the previous value around and adds a little extra code.

rule.name: Syntax error
rule.description: Cppcheck cannot tokenize the code correctly.

rule.name: Internal cppcheck error
rule.description: Analysis failed. If the code is valid then please report this failure.

rule.name: Redundant forward declaration
rule.description: Forward declaration unnecessary, already declared.

rule.name: Variable hides enumerator with same name
rule.description: Variable hides enumerator with same name.

rule.name: Variable hides typedef with same name
rule.description: Variable hides typedef with same name

rule.name: Unnecessary qualification
rule.description: Extra qualification is unnecessary and considered an error by many compilers.

rule.name: Missing include
rule.description: An include file cannot be found.

rule.name: Preprocessor directive error
rule.description: Preprocessor directive error.

rule.name: Possible leak in public function
rule.description: Possible leak in public function. The pointer is not deallocated before it is allocated.

rule.name: The size argument is given as a char constant
rule.description: The size argument is given as a char constant.

rule.name: Buffer is not zero-terminated
rule.description: A buffer is not zero-terminated after a call to a function.

rule.name: Member variable is in wrong order in the initializer list
rule.description: Member variable is in wrong order in the initializer list.

rule.name: Possible buffer overflow if strlen(source) is larger than or equal to sizeof(destination)
rule.description:
Possible buffer overflow if strlen(source) is larger than or equal to sizeof(destination). The source buffer is larger than or equal the destination buffer so there is the potential for overflowing the destination buffer.

References

ARR30-C. Do not form or use out-of-bounds pointers or array subscripts

CWE-398: Indicator of Poor Code Quality

rule.name: Return the address of a function parameter
rule.description:
Address of the function parameter 'varname' becomes invalid after the function exits because function parameters are stored on the stack which is freed when the function exits. Thus the returned value is invalid.

rule.name: Invalid usage of BOOST_FOREACH
rule.description:
BOOST_FOREACH caches the end() iterator. It's undefined behavior if you modify the container inside.

rule.description: Statements following return, break, continue, goto or throw will never be executed.

rule.description: It is inefficient to call 'str.find(str)' as it always returns 0.

rule.name: Redundant condition is always true
rule.description:
Redundant condition: If x > 11 the condition x > 10 is always true.

CWE-398: Indicator of Poor Code Quality

rule.name: Invalid pointer casting
rule.description: This casting is not portable due to different binary data representations on different platforms.

rule.name: Base classes should have virtual destructors
rule.description:
Class Base which is inherited by class Derived does not have a virtual destructor.

References

CWE-404: Improper Resource Shutdown or Release

rule.name: Memory leak across function calls
rule.description:
Memory allocated inside the called function is not freed by the caller function.

References

CWE-772: Missing Release of Resource after Effective Lifetime

rule.name: Redundant c_str()-conversion in functions return
rule.description: Returning the result of c_str() in a function that returns std::string is slow and redundant.

rule.name: Redundant c_str()-conversion in parameter passing
rule.description: Passing the result of c_str() to a function that takes std::string as argument 0 is slow and redundant.

rule.name: Missing bounds check for extra iterator increment in loop
rule.description: Missing bounds check for extra iterator increment in loop. The iterator incrementing is suspicious - it is incremented at line 'line-number-1' and then at line 'line-number-2' The loop might unintentionally skip an element in the container. There is no comparison between these increments to prevent that the iterator is incremented beyond the end.

rule.name: Dangerous usage of strncat
rule.description: Dangerous usage of strncat - 3rd parameter is the maximum number of characters to append. strncat appends at max its 3rd parameter's amount of characters. The safe way to use strncat is to calculate remaining space in the buffer and use it as 3rd parameter.

rule.name: Returning an integer in a function with pointer return type is not portable
rule.description:
Returning an integer (int/long/etc) in a function with pointer return type is not portable across different platforms and compilers. For example in 32-bit Windows and Linux they are same width, but in 64-bit Windows and Linux they are of different width. In worst case you end up casting 64-bit integer down to 32-bit pointer. The safe way is to always return a pointer.

References

CWE-758: Reliance on Undefined, Unspecified, or Implementation-Defined Behavior

rule.name: Read and write operations without a call to a positioning function
rule.description:
Read and write operations without a call to a positioning function (fseek, fsetpos or rewind) or fflush in between result in undefined behavior.

References

CWE-664: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime

rule.description:

rule.name: member variable shall be initialized using constructor
rule.description:
When an object of a class is created, the constructors of all member variables are called consecutively in the order the variables are declared, even if you don't explicitly write them to the initialization list. You could avoid assigning 'symbol' a value by passing the value to the constructor in the initialization list.

rule.name: Check statement and clarify behavior

rule.name: Too many #ifdef configurations - cppcheck only checks 12 configurations
rule.description:
Too many #ifdef configurations - cppcheck only checks 12 configurations. Use --force to check all configurations. For more details, use --enable=information.

CWE-398: Indicator of Poor Code Quality

rule.name: Returning an address value in a function with integer return type is not portable
rule.description:
Returning an address value in a function with integer (int/long/etc) return type is not portable across different platforms and compilers. For example in 32-bit Windows and Linux they are same width, but in 64-bit Windows and Linux they are of different width. In worst case you end up casting 64-bit address down to 32-bit integer. The safe way is to always return an integer.

rule.name: Assert with side effect

rule.name: scanf without field width limits can crash
rule.description: scanf without field width limits can crash with huge input data on some versions of libc.

rule.name: memset is used on class which contains a floating point number
rule.description:
Using memset() on class which contains a floating point number. This is not portable because memset() sets each byte of a block of memory to a specific value and the actual representation of a floating-point value is implementation defined. Note: In case of an IEEE754-1985 compatible implementation setting all bits to zero results in the value 0.0.

References

CWE-590: Free of Memory not on the Heap

rule.name: Using memory function on class that contains references
rule.description:
Using "memfunc" on class that contains a reference.

References

CWE-590: Free of Memory not on the Heap

rule.name: Member variable is initialized by itself.
rule.description:
Member variable 'var' is initialized by itself.

References

CWE-665: Improper Initialization

rule.name: Shifting 32-bit value by 64 bits is undefined behaviour
rule.description:
Shifting 32-bit value by 64 bits is undefined behaviour.

References

INT34-C. Do not shift an expression by a negative number of bits or by greater than or equal to the number of bits that exist in the operand

CWE-758: Reliance on Undefined, Unspecified, or Implementation-Defined Behavior

rule.name: Suspicious sign conversion of var in calculation
rule.description: Suspicious code: sign conversion of var in calculation, even though var can have a negative value.

rule.name: Suspicious calculation of memset() bytes size
rule.description: Division by result of sizeof(). memset() expects a size in bytes, did you intend to multiply instead?

rule.name: Avoid loss of precision for expression
rule.description: Expression '1 - erf(x)' can be replaced by 'erfc(x)' to avoid loss of precision.

rule.name: Assignment of function parameter has no effect outside the function
rule.description:
Assignment of function parameter has no effect outside the function.

References

CWE-398: Indicator of Poor Code Quality

rule.name: va_list not closed by va_end()
rule.description:
va_list 'vl' was opened but not closed by va_end().

References

CWE-664: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime

rule.name: va_list used before va_start() call
rule.description:
va_list 'vl' used before va_start() was called.

References

CWE-664: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime

rule.name: Using reference as parameter for va_start() is undefined behaviour
rule.description:
Using reference 'arg1' as parameter for va_start() results in undefined behaviour.

References

CWE-758: Reliance on Undefined, Unspecified, or Implementation-Defined Behavior

rule.name: va_start() or va_copy() called without va_end() inbetween
rule.description:
va_start() or va_copy() called subsequently on 'vl' without va_end() inbetween.

References

CWE-664: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime

rule.name: Given argument to va_start() is not last one
rule.description: 'arg1' given to va_start() is not last named argument of the function. Did you intend to pass 'arg2'?.

rule.name: Unmatched suppression: unusedFunction
rule.description: Unmatched suppression: unusedFunction.

rule.name: Same expression in both branches of ternary operator
rule.description: Same expression in both branches of ternary operator.

rule.name: Class has a constructor with 1 argument that is not explicit
rule.description: Class 'classname' has a constructor with 1 argument that is not explicit.

rule.name: Abstract class has a copy/move constructor that is not explicit
rule.description: Abstract class 'classname' has a copy/move constructor that is not explicit.

rule.name: Missing 'return' statement in non-void function causes undefined behavior
rule.description:
No return statement in non-void function causes undefined behavior.

References

CWE-398: Indicator of Poor Code Quality

rule.name: 'operator=' should either return reference to 'this'
rule.description:
'operator=' should either return reference to 'this'instance or be declared private and left unimplemented.

References

CWE-398: Indicator of Poor Code Quality

rule.name: Redundant pointer operation on varname
rule.description: Redundant pointer operation on varname - it's already a pointer.

rule.name: Exception thrown in function declared not to throw exceptions
rule.description: Exception thrown in function declared not to throw exceptions.

rule.name: Object pointed by an 'auto_ptr' is destroyed using operator 'delete'
rule.description: Object pointed by an 'auto_ptr' is destroyed using operator 'delete'. You should not use 'auto_ptr' for pointers obtained with function 'malloc'.

rule.name: Declaration of array 'identifier' with negative size is undefined behaviour
rule.description:
Declaration of array 'identifier' with negative size is undefined behaviour.

References

ARR32-C. Ensure size arguments for variable length arrays are in a valid range

rule.name: Result of operator '|' is always true if one operand is non-zero
rule.description: Result of operator '|' is always true if one operand is non-zero. Did you intend to use '&'?

rule.name: Condition 'x' is always true
rule.description: Condition 'x' is always true.

rule.name: Possible null pointer dereference if the default parameter value is used: pointer
rule.description:
Possible null pointer dereference if the default parameter value is used: pointer.

References

EXP34-C. Do not dereference null pointers

rule.name: Either the condition is redundant or there is possible null pointer dereference: pointer
rule.description:
Either the condition is redundant or there is possible null pointer dereference: pointer.

References

EXP34-C. Do not dereference null pointers

rule.name: Obsolete function 'alloca' called
rule.description: Obsolete function 'alloca' called. In C99 and later it is recommended to use a variable length array instead.

rule.name: Race condition: non-interlocked access after InterlockedDecrement()
rule.description: Race condition: non-interlocked access after InterlockedDecrement(). Use InterlockedDecrement() return value instead.

rule.name: Label 'identifier' is not used
rule.description: Label 'identifier' is not used.

rule.name: Modifying string literal directly or indirectly is undefined behaviour
rule.description: Modifying string literal directly or indirectly is undefined behaviour.

rule.name: int result is assigned to long variable (potential truncation)
rule.description: int result is assigned to long variable. If the variable is long to avoid loss of information, then you have loss of information.

rule.name: int result is returned as long value (potential truncation)
rule.description: int result is returned as long value. If the return value is long to avoid loss of information, then you have loss of information.

rule.name: Boolean value assigned to floating point variable
rule.description: Boolean value assigned to floating point variable.

rule.name: Invalid test for overflow (undefined behavior)
rule.description: Invalid test for overflow 'x + u < x'. Condition is always false unless there is overflow, and overflow is UB.

rule.name: Expression depends on order of evaluation (side effects)
rule.description: Expression 'x = x++;' depends on order of evaluation of side effects.

rule.name: Signed 'char' type used as array index
rule.description: Signed 'char' type used as array index. If the value can be greater than 127 there will be a buffer underflow because of sign extension.

rule.name: 'char' type used as array index
rule.description: 'char' type used as array index. Values greater that 127 will be treated depending on whether 'char' is signed or unsigned on target platform.

rule.name: Label is not used.
rule.description: Label is not used.
